data.title: Remove the emmet encode/decode action for June
data.body: We want to make another iteration on the implementation. See #8569.

data.title: Search: do not show preview when replace is empty?
data.body:
Marking important for discussion: I find it weird at the moment that clicking a search result opens the preview of replace only because I have the replace input field expanded:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/900690/16515162/a9aa825a-3f70-11e6-8b50-b6e2568bdcc4.png)

It is especially bad because the results all show in the color of a normal search result.

I suggest that for this case when you click on a result, we just open it like a search result.

data.title: Introduce an universal newline character like \R
JSON: this._ruleStack.equals is not a function
data.body:
Got this opening my settings file running "out of source" and changing a boolean from false to true:

```
TypeError: this._ruleStack.equals is not a function
    at TMState.equals (TMState.js:33)
    at Model.TextModelWithTokens._updateTokensUntilLine (textModelWithTokens.js:538)
    at Model.TextModelWithTokens._revalidateTokensNow (textModelWithTokens.js:457)
    at textModelWithTokens.js:410
```

@alexandrudima fyi

data.title: Debugger issue with Node.js/TypeScript code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04

Steps to Reproduce:

I came across an issue with VS Code debugger when debugging Node.js/TypeScript code in a specific situation described below.

In TypeScript, when using "let" to declare a variable inside a try/catch block, and when using that variable inside a callback within the same try/catch block, the debugger won't read the variable, instead it appends "_1" and displays a variable copy in the Variables window. The code works, it's just the debugger that's acting strange.

When using var instead of let, or when not using try/catch, there is no problem.

Screenshot of the described situation:
http://take.ms/a2iJC

I compiled an example Node.js project which reproduces an issue, you can open it in Visual Studio Code, Run Build Task, place a breakpoint in test.ts and just start debugging. Download it here:
https://www.dropbox.com/s/jxk0upjppqkiunw/example.tar.gz?dl=1

This could very well be a Node.js bug, but I am not sure. Please advise.

Regards,

Igor

data.title: VSCode should display information regarding languages' versions
Improve the Code update experience

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body: The current Code Updates are highly annoying and highly intrusive! Please find a way to make the updates less intrusive... the Visual Studio way with a flag and number is sooo much better! I can understand that your policy is constant updates, but it feels like part of me starting up Code is to do an update first! It is uber annoying. Then after the update, I still have to see that annoying update bar about what the update did... seriously just get out of the way and let me work!

data.title: Ctrl+k Ctrl+P not mapped to showAllEditors
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.3.0-insiders
- OS Version:Windows 10

The obsolete command workbench.files.action.workingFilesPicker had been mapped to ctrl+k ctrl+p.
The new equivalent command is workbench.action.showAllEditors.  

showAllEditors is mapped to alt+cmd+tab for OS X but not mapped for Windows and Linux.

data.title: No 'Stage Selected Lines
data.body:

5. select lines in the right pane of the diff viewer

data.title: Rendering issues with VSCode on Ubuntu in VirtualBox
data.body:
Version 1.2.1
Commit fe7f407b95b7f78405846188259504b34ef72761
Datum 2016-06-14T12:54:38.105Z
Shell 0.37.6
Renderer 49.0.2623.75
Node 5.10.0
OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04 LTS

Steps to Reproduce:
1. I have a Ubuntu installed on VirtualBox with graphics acceleration enabled and 128MB of graphics memory
2. I freshly installed VSCode on the fresh Ubuntu installation
3. VSCode does not render properly
4. Also VSCode is always in the foreground (on top of all other windows)
5. I have a separate virtual machine with the latest version of Linux Mint installed and there I have no problem with the rendering, since both virtual machines have the same setting, I guess it has nothing to do with VirtualBox
6. Funny enough, when I take a screen shot I only get this, which is not the actual rendering problem I see, when not taking a screen shot. Normally I only see the dark gray background of VSCode, some lighter gray patches, and the cursor:
   ![Screenshot](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10341491/16504176/e1eaabd6-3f16-11e6-9490-166118cddd27.png)

data.title: Bgashler1/color b
data.body:
Alternate version, based on feedback from PR #8238.

Changes:
- Removed scroll decoration modifications (they are default now)
- Removed gradient trick and now instead use the viewlet background color so the tab well still is different from the find/replace.  The first tab with its own background, in turn, is able to differentiate the tab well from the viewlet, so everything is clearly separated.
- Made inactive tabs have their own background color that is different from tab well.

This also addresses all feedback in https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/8564

Thanks @bpasero and @isidorn for your feedback.  I'm sure we can continue refining this in July.

data.title: Emmet: show error when the path is located outside the current workspace
data.body:
Source: #8569
#### Description

Just show error when the path is located outside the current workspace.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7034281/16498683/8f0ff68e-3f05-11e6-8bc0-2237f7f35ce3.png)
#### About `createPath` function

It's not necessary to check. The function `createPath` only used in [base64.js](https://github.com/emmetio/emmet/blob/3a946a2ca2c4b0e5878547dab9911e04edc1bd64/lib/action/base64.js#L84) action:

``` js
var absPath = file.createPath(editor.getFilePath(), filePath);
```

The method (`editor.getFilePath()`) always returns the real path to the **file**.

``` ts
public getFilePath(): string {
    return this.editor.getModel().uri.fsPath;
}
```

data.title: Strange CLI behavior: CLI does not seem to write to either stdout (FD 1) or stderr (FD 2), making output impossible to redirect.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code - Insiders 1.3.0-insider (a21c12346f388e51858c930875ca30968604c116, 2016-06-30T05:07:11.570Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14372

Strange CLI behavior: the VS Code CLI does not seem to write to either stdout (FD 1) or stderr (FD 2), making output impossible to pipe to e.g. `grep` to search for a particular flag, and making it impossible to hide output in scripting (not that I can think of a good reason you would want to script the `code` CLI).

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Run `code-insiders -h > NUL` from cmd
2. Observe that output is still printed
3. Run `code-insiders -h 1> NUL` from cmd
4. Observe that output is still printed
5. Run `code-insiders -h 2> NUL` from cmd
6. Observe that output is still printed

data.title: [json] improve anyof handling

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: Version 1.2.1 (1.2.1)
- OS Version: 10.11.5 (15F34)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Download [test.json](https://gist.github.com/Sequoia/d86032bff4413759c2f27e9cf852817b) and load it into VS Code
2. Delete & recreate the `"test"` property

Problems:
1. It does not prompt you for an object type, indicating null & string are the only valid types:
   ![screenshot 2016-06-30 13 01 37](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/317498/16497226/e1253f84-3ec3-11e6-92f7-f6ffdbd22929.png)
2. If the object type is invalid, **intellisense defaults to the first available type**. What it should do is say, approximately: "there is an object type available but you have illegal keys in it."
   ![bad-type](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/317498/16497282/1779fe1c-3ec4-11e6-8492-2deb00ff8b1a.gif)
3. Does the same if string is not a legal string (from `enum`):
   ![bad-type](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/317498/16497518/6ac4c826-3ec5-11e6-9067-0d5fdb0668da.gif)

data.title: Open preview action on a markdown file opens the preview again if it is already opened in a different editor group

milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: a21c12346f388e51858c930875ca30968604c116
- OS Version: OSX

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Tabs enabled
2. Open a markdown file
3. Right click on the tab and open Preview
4. Drag and drop the opened preview into a second editor group
5. Right click on the preview tab and open source
6. Note that it makes already opened markdown file as active
7. Now again right click on the markdown tab and open Preview

Expected: It makes already opened preview as active
Actual: It opens new Preview tab next to it

data.title: Allow to have scoped instantiation service per editor slot
data.body:
For:
- scoped keybinding service
- scoped progress service

For the title area and the editor itself. This requires a common parent (or the editor-container itself) to be reparented instead of the editor moving around.

Enables more scenarios around menu and command contributions for contexts.

data.title: Restore target environments in common & browser
data.body:
Some parts in workbench dragged in dependencies to upstream environments (common => browser, browser => electron-browser).

**Original:**

First of all thank you for making a standalone version of `monaco` available. It is the greatest online editor and most people don't need more than that. But I was using `monaco-workbench`, its services and UI infrastructure in a custom web project, similar to vs online.

Thanks to great source structure my implementation was working very good until a recent change to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/src/vs/workbench/browser/workbench.ts#L47 which references from `electron-browser` and prevents it to be used in web.

I know it has not been the intent to make everything reusable, but it would be greatly appreciated if the team maintain the code in a way to keep `browser` modules available in web for use cases like this.

data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.2.1
- OS Version: various / many

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Open a file in VSCode
2. Click the filename at the top left of the file pane (this opens the command palette)
3. Close all files in VSCode (this shows a blank pane with the VSCode logo)
4. Click the same location (currently blank - nothing happens - command palette is no longer accessible via mouse)

_Quite a low-priority feature request as I'm primarily a keyboard user, but it would be nice if it were fully mouse-accessible in all editor states._

data.title: Ctrl-k (kill to end of line) does not delete empty line.
data.body:
VSCode Version:
Version 1.3.0-insider (1.3.0-insider)
a21c123
2016-06-30T05:01:53.185Z

OS Version:
OSX 10.11.5 (15F34)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In a new document, type 'a' and then return for a newline.
2. Place the editor caret in front of 'a'.
3. Press ctrl-k twice.

In any standard OSX text area, this results in the text 'a' being killed, then the second kill deletes the empty line.
In VS Code, the 'a' gets killed, but the second kill has no effect.

As a user habituated to the standard text commands, this is very annoying, because it prevents me from quickly deleting multiple lines of text; instead, I have to alternate between ctrl-k and ctrl-d.

data.title: Ctrl-t (transpose) command inserts extra character.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
- VSCode Version:
  Version 1.3.0-insider (1.3.0-insider)
  a21c12346f388e51858c930875ca30968604c116
  2016-06-30T05:01:53.185Z
- OS Version:
  OSX 10.11.5 (15F34)

Steps to Reproduce:
1. In a new document, type 'ab'.
2. Place the editor caret between the two characters.
3. Press `ctrl-t`.

In any standard OSX text area, this results in the text 'ba'.
In VS Code, the result is 'bab', which I cannot imagine justifying as desirable.

Note that there is a separate behavior when the caret is at end-of-line: in the EOL case, the previous two characters are transposed. VS Code handles this correctly; it is only the "in between" case that is broken (as far as I can tell). Any fix should make sure to test both cases.
